docblock.description: This class is designed to allow to you to pass in the class name and its dependencies to then allow you to return a object of that class.
docblock.long-description:
There is a data structure that allows you to pass in the classes despendencies.

$dependencies = array(
    'class_name' => array(
        'params' => array(
           'class_param',
           'class_param2'
        )
    ),
);

Then all you need to do:

$object = AisisCore_Factory_Pattern::create('class_name')
// From there you can do:
$object->class_name_method();

docblock.description: This interface is used to create the admin panel for WordPress themes.
docblock.long-description: This interface allows for you to set up a class that allows for the developer of the WordPress theme to create an admin panel. We provide the baic methods, such as the abillity to create a menu (including submenus), set up the settings and allows for you to create a global validator for your options and finally a function to register a template used for the admin panel it's self.

docblock.description: Allows you to set up a menu, including sub menus.
Allows you to register any settings used for the admin options of your theme.
Allows you to register a template or set one up for use as your template for the admin panel.
docblock.long-description: This then gets called into the menu_setup() function under the function option for the navigation.

docblock.description: This interface is meant to be used for doing upgrades to your theme.
docblock.long-description:
When implementing this class we check the current theme version against that of the remote version, ve it in an xml file or some where else.

We then get the latest version of the theme and then - delete the contents, accept for some required files of the theme (only if we need to), and then from there we simply replace the current files with those in the zip.

Note: we use the version in the style.css to compare against whats remote.

docblock.description: Check if there is an update or not.
Upgrade, by replacing the current files with that of the new files.

docblock.description: This class inherits the subsection functionality to allow forms to have one subsection.
docblock.long-description:
This class is to be extended by any class that creates a form. that class is then called into the template where you want that form to be displated. From there you pass it a data structure such as:

$array = array(
   'method' => 'post',
   'action' => 'your form action',
   'class' => 'css class',
   'id' => 'css id'
);

This array then gets passed to the constructor of this class when instantiating it in the the template.

When you go to create a form you extend this class, create a series of protected functions that will be the elements, from there you pass those into the init method of that class and with in there you do $this->_create_form().

All forms can have one sub section, these sub sections are shown above the submit button but bellow all elements.

docblock.description: Takes in and sets a seris of options.
When extending this class, this is where you create and array of elements and then call that array into the create_form() along with any other options.
Returns the method or returns null.
Returns the action or returns null.
Simply opens the form.
docblock.long-description: Based on the options you pass into the constructor of this class, we will open the form tag with those options.

docblock.description: This will display a series of elements that belong to the form.
docblock.long-description: This includes the sub_section of the form.

docblock.description: This will close the form.
This will create the form based on options that you pass in.
docblock.long-description:
We take in an array of elements for the form, the forms subsection and if we are dealing with an admin panel, the settings for that form.

We also display content for comment forms as well.

docblock.description: This function is identicle to the settings_fields in WordPress.
docblock.long-description: The main key difference between this version and the WordPress version of this function is that instead of echoing out the hidden fields, we are concatenating them to $_html so that we can then print them out inside the form tags.

docblock.description: This class will allow you to create a checkbox based element.
docblock.long-description:
This class will create you a checbox element that you can then use in your form. To make it checked your value should be the value that is coming from the options array. That is, for example 'aisis_core['check']' would be the name. the option would be aisis_core, then the key out be check while the value would be check.

The options being passed in would look something like:

$checkbox = array(
   'id' => 'css id',
   'class' => 'css class',
   'name' => 'options['option_name']',
   'value' => 'option_name',
   'option' => 'options',
   'key' => 'option_name',
   'required' => 'true',
   'label' => 'string label',
      'disabled' => true //disable the element
);

docblock.description: This class is meant to be extended to create view helpers essentially.
docblock.long-description:
these view helpers are things like containers with content inside of them, or headers above form sections and so on.

The following is a good example of a for helper:

 public function sub_form_content(){
    $options = array(
        'class' => 'well',
        'content' => '
Choose from one of the following to display your posts
        on on the front page.
'
    );

    $content = new AisisCore_Form_Helpers_DisplayContent($options);

    return $content;
}

This will create the following:


    
Choose from one of the following to display your posts
       on on the front page.

Helpers are used to create quick html elements for forms, they are then used with the form to display some kind of content.

docblock.description: We take in an array of options that can then be processed by the child class to construct the helper.
Over ride me with constructor like variables and methods as I get called in the constructor.
docblock.long-description: Never over ride the constructor of this class.

docblock.description: This is the content we set for the helper.
docblock.long-description: This can be things like the object, elements, text or what ever. You can use html based elements.

docblock.description: Return what ever content is that you set.

parse_markers.error: No page-level DocBlock was found in file AisisCore/Form/Helpers/Content.php

docblock.description: This class is extended by both forms and elements to allow for them to have subsections.
docblock.long-description:
Sub sections in Aisis Core are sections that are a set of elements that are related to either the element in question or the form its self.

It is known that each form may have one sub section that will appear above the submit element but below the rest of the elements.

How ever each element, including sub section elements, can have a sub section that contains multiple elements. those in turn, as stated can also have a sub section.

Sub sections are created by the data structure listed bellow:

$array = array(
    'sub_elements' => array(
        //elements
    ),
    'sub_content_options' => array(
        'class' => 'sample class',
        'sub_elements_div' => array(
            'class' => 'sample class'
        ),
    ),
);

This array is then passed into either the create_form() for the sub section or into the instantiation of that form object as a sub section of the form.

docblock.description: Simple constructor that calls in the init.
Use this to pass in constructor params.
This will wrap the sub section elements in a div.
docblock.long-description: This will open the div with either the clas or the id or both if both are set.

docblock.description: Each element will be wrapped in a div, if that is set.
docblock.long-description: we will also set a label for that element.

docblock.description: Close the sub section div.
Returns the html as a string.

docblock.long-description:
This class is responsible for creating a element based on a set of attributes you pass to it in the form of an array. That is we take that array of options and create an element that is then considered valid html.

The set of options you pass is is dependent on the element you are creating.

docblock.description: Constructor for creating an element.
docblock.long-description:
Each element has a set of options, specific to that element. Each element can contain a sub section of elements.

This constructor is set up a bit differently the others, we register any options set first, call the init and then and only then set up the sub sections for that element.

This allows for the element to have the sub section appear bellow the element being created.

docblock.description: Easy and efficient way of building loops with in template files.
docblock.long-description:
This class is designed to allow for you to build loops with in your own theme or theme framework.

To use this class all you have to do is create a data structure that you can pass to the constructor of this class.

$options = array(
    'title_header' => 'h1', // h1, h2, h3, h4
    'excerpt' => array(
            'length' => 60, // # of words
            'content' => 'More...' // The title of the link for the read more.
        ),
        'post_before' => '', // Something before the post in an index list.
        'post_after' => '', // Something after the post in an index list,
        // Used for the general index.
        'image' => array(
            'size' => 'medium', // The size given by WordPress.
            'args' => array(), // Image arguments given by WordPress.
        ),
        'single' => array(
            'show_categories' => true, // Or false
            'show_tags' => true, // Or false
            'image' => array(
                'size' => 'medium', // The size given by WordPress.
                'args' => array(), // Image arguments given by WordPress.
            ),
        )
        'query' => array(), // The main query given by WordPress.
        '404_template' => '' // The path to said template or a message.
);

This data structure is then passed into the class constructor like so:

$loop = new AisisCore_Template_Loop($options);
$loop->loop();

If you choose to pass in no arguments we will use defaults for everything.

We also deal with pagination, reseting the query and dealing with checking if you are on a single page or. All you need is to call the class and the function.

docblock.description: Set the wp_query object as a class level object if the class level object is empty and the options.
docblock.long-description:
Set the options and the wp_query object.

Add new actions to excerpt_length and excerpt_more.

docblock.description: Use this to make any overrides to class.
Sets up the loop for the WordPress Theme.
docblock.long-description:
If we have options, then we check if were a single. If not do we have a query? if not then we just do the general loop.

If none of this is true, we check the single.

If we are not on the single post and the options are not set then we we will just call the general loop.

If the single page is rendered, we also take care of loading the comments.php file as well.

docblock.description: This is the most basic loop.
docblock.long-description: All were doing is returning a list of posts.

docblock.description: Allows you to display a list of posts based on the query passed in.
docblock.long-description:
Based on the query passed in we will display a list of posts. Pagination is dealt with as well as reseting the query.

Please make sure you pass in the following to the query to make sure that pagination works:

$paged = (get_query_var('paged')) ? get_query_var('paged') : 1;

docblock.description: This function will supply the single template with the post and it's contents.
This loop uses the same concept of single, but with out the tags, categories and navigation.
Builds loop navigation for the general and the queried loop.
Builds Navigation for single posts.
Disaply a sidebar so long as the options key does not match.
docblock.long-description: Also to be used in conjunction with WordPress conditionals.

docblock.description: Based on if were single, a title_header or if were an index we will then display the title.
Builds a previous link.
Builds a next link.
Rendered a 404 template if you have created one or renders out a message.
docblock.long-description: If you have created a 404 phtml file in your theme or even a 404.php then you can place the path in $options[404_template] and we will render that view for when no posts are found on either a queried loop, regular loop or a single loop.

docblock.description: Gets a list of categories based on the post.
Gets a list of tags based on the post.
The new excerpt_length added into action
The new content for excerpt_more added into the action.

parse_markers.error: No page-level DocBlock was found in file AisisCore/Template/Helpers/Loop.php

docblock.description: This class is used to build templates or to register the templates based on options.
docblock.long-description:
We take in two core peices of information. Any options, this would be wordpress options.

These options come from the admin panel that you would create with the options you would set.

Based on this, if the options are set we return an array of options that we can then use.

The array datastructure we accept for this class is:

$array = array(
    admin_options => 'admin_option'
    template_view_path => 'path'
)

docblock.description: Set all the values and take in any options or pages we have set.
docblock.long-description: We set the options, its best to have a set of wordpress options such as 'aisis_core' for example, which in this case would be a set of options that were saved from the admin panel.

docblock.description: When overriding this class, place all your constructor buisness here.
Set all options into an array of key=>value.
Return an option by a name that is specified.
docblock.long-description: Throw an error if the option name we are looking for does not exist.

docblock.description: Get a value from either an array of arrays or an associative array of options.
docblock.long-description:
All options are gottem back as an associtive array, or an associative array of arrays. This function will walk through each object in the array comparing the key to that of the key you passed in and will search for the key in the array. If found we return the value.

Example: If you have an option such as aisis_core['sidebar'] and its balue is true. You would pass in sidebar as your key and get back true.

in the set up you can set up the admin_options key to be:

'admin_options' => array('options_name', 'another_name');

//Looking for option_name[_name_value] with avalue of 'bob'?

get_specific_option('_name_value');

//returns bob.

docblock.description: Return all theme options.
Returns true or false if the theme options is an array or not.
Delete options and redirect to the index page with a variable of reset.
docblock.long-description: resualting url will be site.com/wp-admin/index.php?reset=true

docblock.description: Renders a template from a registered template_view_path or an array of paths.
docblock.long-description:
This function requires that you have set either the value of template_view_path to that of a path or an array of paths inside of $_options.

We will render the template name passed in. no need to pass in the template+extension as all templates need to be .phtml based. We will append the extension on to the file name.

We also allow you to pass in an array of templat names in the fashion of $type=>$name.

docblock.description: Check every path for every file in the array of templates and files.
docblock.long-description:
We take an array of template in $type=>$name format and an array of template paths as $template=>$path and then we search each path for each file and load them. We make sure to throw appropriate errors if we cannot find said file at any path.

We load only .phtml files. You only need to pass in the name of the file and not its extension.

docblock.description: look in an array of paths for a particular file based on the name.
docblock.long-description:
We take in an array of template paths and a single name (with out exteension). We then attempt to find that file in those paths, making sure to throw an error if the template is not found.

All templates have a .phtml extension.

parse_markers.error: No page-level DocBlock was found in file AisisCore/Template/Builder.php

docblock.description: Class for dealing with template cased exceptions.

parse_markers.error: No page-level DocBlock was found in file AisisCore/Template/TemplateException.php

docblock.description: This class is used to load a package of code.
docblock.long-description:
The core purpose of this class is to load two types of packages, custom and internal.

Custom packages live in the custom/packages folder and are custom to each theme. This allows the theme some flexabillity. All custom packages need to contain a Setup.php which is then loaded by the theme.

Internal packages are packages that are internal to the theme. That is, packages which help the theme run or are dependant to the theme.

<

p>The basic structure of a package is such that:

<

p>

PackageName |-- Files, Folders, Assets ... |-- Setup.php

docblock.description: Simple constructor.
Use this when overriding the class.
We will load a internal or custom package if you are or not a child theme.
docblock.long-description:
We give you a series of options to try and determine what type of package you are loading. Custom packages do not need or require a dir path passed in as we have that set in stone.

The package name is the name of the folder the Setup.php file is inside of, this is the root folder.

The child option will only load a package if the current active theme is not a child theme. For child themes who want to implement features turned off to them, they have to recall the load_package() function with appropriate params passed in.

tag.name: param
tag.description: - Name of the root foldr the Setup.php is inside of.

tag.name: param
tag.description: | optional $dir - The path to the package, used for internal.

tag.name: param
tag.description: | optional $custom - Should we look in the custom/packages folder?

tag.name: param
tag.description: | optional $child - Load only when not achild theme?

docblock.description: This function takes only the name of the package.
docblock.long-description: This function is responsible for loading the package assuming that package is not empty or that it exists.

docblock.description: This function is meant to load internal packages.
docblock.long-description: Any package you create that contains a Setup.php file will be loaded if you pass in the directory of package and its name.

docblock.description: Allows you to load a single file from a package.
docblock.long-description: When passing in the package all you need to do is pass in the name. we will find the package and the file and the require it.

docblock.description: Checks if a package exists or not.
Checks if a package is empty or not.

docblock.description: This class is responsible for loaifing and auto loading classes based on the path structure.
docblock.long-description:
This class should be instantiated first before all else, as it will allow you to call classes or instantiate classes with out having to do a require_once() or an include any where in the file.

Classes need to be path/to/class.php This means that classes need to be named: path_to_class

This class is not to be instantiated as an object but instead you would do:

new AisisCore_Loader_AutoLoader::get_instance()

docblock.description: Returns an instance of the of the class.

docblock.description: This class is responsible for setting up the theme and it's core componenets.
docblock.long-description:
We take in an array that looks like:

$options = array(
   'widgets' => array(),
   'navigation' => array(),
      'theme_support' => array(
       'post_formats' = array(),
       'thumbnails' => array(
           'exceptions' => array(),
       )
   ),
   'custom_theme' => array(
       'custom-header' => array(),
       'custom-background' => array()
   )

);

This then gets called into the class such as:

$theme = new AisisCore_Theme($options);

At any point you may call one of the public functions below to change the options, making sure to set the appopriate $key, $value in the $options array.

docblock.description: Set the options that are passed in assuming they are an array of options.
Override me when extending this class, pass all constructor logic here.
Register all sidebar options.
docblock.long-description:
Depends upon $options['widgets'] to register the widgetized areas. This can be an array of associative arrays that is:

'widgets' => array(
    'sidebar' => array(),
    'footer' => array(),
);

docblock.description: Register all navigation options.
docblock.long-description: Depends upon $options['navigation'] to register the navigation.

docblock.description: Adds various post formats to a theme.
docblock.long-description: Depends upon $options['theme_support']['post_formats'], which is an array of post formats to register the various post formats.

docblock.description: Allows you to add thumb nail support to posts.
docblock.long-description: By default we add support for this, assuming you have not filled out the $options['theme_support']['thumbnails']['exceptions'] arrays which takes in a list of formats where you do not want to include post thumbnails.

docblock.description: Adds support for custom-background and custom-header.
docblock.long-description: Depends upon $options['core_theme'] array which contains the two main peices: custom-header and custom-background.

docblock.description: This is a new form that allows you to create tabbed forms.
docblock.long-description:
This means that no matter the tab you are on with in the form you can hit submit at any time. This type of form use an array of elements to create the elemts for said tab.

The following is an example of how to set up one tab in the tabbed form.

$array = array(
        'method' => 'post',
    'action' => 'options.php',
    'class' => 'form-vertical',
    'settings' => 'aisis_options',
    array(
        'tab' => 'Posts',
        'elements' => array(
            $posts->elements()
        ),
    ),
 );

docblock.description: Create the tabs.
Create the elements with in the tabs.

docblock.description: This asset loader is use to load the assets of either font end or admin based on the key pased in.
docblock.long-description:
We will load either the asset of the front end or the admin back end, both js and or css.

To do this we need to set up an array, this array is set up like such: 

// This will set up the css
$scripts_to_load  = array(
  'css' => array(
      array(
          'name'=>'core-css',
          'path'=>get_bloginfo('stylesheet_url')
      ),
);

// Other keys to use are:
// js_jquery, admin_js_jquery, admin_css, js, admin_js

docblock.description: This class is responsible for creating a sub section called Rows.
docblock.long-description: When displaying posts on the home page, you have the option of lists, rows or general. This will allow you to pick up to 3, 6 or 9 posts to display in rows of three. This will not display sticky posts. You also have the option of displaying a read more button by entering a link hat should link to a page with the content on it.
